step1_initial_points.title: Lack of AI Market Awareness
step1_initial_points.description: The Department lacks a clear understanding of the current AI tools and services available. This makes it difficult to plan projects or procurement, prompting them to create a "catalogue of offerings" to map the landscape and understand what is possible.

step1_initial_points.title: Ensuring Security and Regulatory Compliance
step1_initial_points.description: The government must adhere to strict ICT, security, and privacy policies (IPPs). There is a significant risk that adopting a new AI tool could lead to non-compliance, creating legal and operational liabilities for the public sector.

step1_initial_points.title: Safeguarding Sensitive Government Data
step1_initial_points.description: Protecting government data is paramount, especially with third-party LLMs. The Department is concerned about how AI solutions will ensure the security and integrity of sensitive information, which is a critical government asset and public trust issue.

step1_initial_points.title: Integration with Existing Legacy Systems
step1_initial_points.description: New AI solutions must function within the existing government IT infrastructure. The Department is concerned about the technical challenges, adaptability, and cost of integrating innovative tools with its current systems and platforms.

step1_initial_points.title: Uncertainty of AI Performance and ROI
step1_initial_points.description: Committing to large-scale AI deployment is risky without proven results. The Department needs to validate the real-world effectiveness and return on investment of AI solutions through smaller pilot initiatives before wider adoption.

step1_initial_points.title: Unpredictable AI Solution Costs
step1_initial_points.description: The Department cannot effectively plan budgets without clear information on AI pricing. They need indicative costing and pricing models to understand the total cost of ownership and allocate funds for future procurement strategies.

step1_initial_points.title: Lack of Proven Government Use Cases
step1_initial_points.description: As a risk-averse public entity, the Department seeks assurance from proven deployments. They need evidence and best practices from successful AI implementations in similar government sectors to build confidence and justify investment.

step1_initial_points.title: Internal Skills Gap and Training Burden
step1_initial_points.description: Implementing new AI tools may require skills current staff do not possess. The Department is concerned about the potential burden of staff training, which could impact project timelines, budget, and the overall success of adoption.

step1_initial_points.title: Pressure to Boost Efficiency & Service Delivery
step1_initial_points.description: The Department is driven by a core need to improve government operations. They are exploring AI to address current inefficiencies, enhance decision-making, improve public service delivery, and achieve better community outcomes.

step1_initial_points.title: Concern over Scalability and Future-Proofing
step1_initial_points.description: The buyer needs solutions that can adapt and grow over time. They are assessing the maturity and scalability of AI tools to ensure any investment is future-proof and can handle evolving government needs and planned enhancements.

step2_filtered_points.description: The government must adhere to strict ICT, security, and privacy policies (IPPs). There is a significant risk that adopting a new AI tool could lead to non-compliance, creating legal and operational liabilities for the public sector.

step2_filtered_points.title: Safeguarding Sensitive Government Data
step2_filtered_points.description: Protecting government data is paramount, especially with third-party LLMs. The Department is concerned about how AI solutions will ensure the security and integrity of sensitive information, which is a critical government asset and public trust issue.

step2_filtered_points.title: Integration with Existing Legacy Systems
step2_filtered_points.description: New AI solutions must function within the existing government IT infrastructure. The Department is concerned about the technical challenges, adaptability, and cost of integrating innovative tools with its current systems and platforms.

step2_filtered_points.title: Uncertainty of AI Performance and ROI
step2_filtered_points.description: Committing to large-scale AI deployment is risky without proven results. The Department needs to validate the real-world effectiveness and return on investment of AI solutions through smaller pilot initiatives before wider adoption.

step2_filtered_points.title: Lack of Proven Government Use Cases
step2_filtered_points.description: As a risk-averse public entity, the Department seeks assurance from proven deployments. They need evidence and best practices from successful AI implementations in similar government sectors to build confidence and justify investment.

step2_filtered_points.title: Internal Skills Gap and Training Burden
step2_filtered_points.description: Implementing new AI tools may require skills current staff do not possess. The Department is concerned about the potential burden of staff training, which could impact project timelines, budget, and the overall success of adoption.

step2_filtered_points.title: Concern over Scalability and Future-Proofing
step2_filtered_points.description: The buyer needs solutions that can adapt and grow over time. They are assessing the maturity and scalability of AI tools to ensure any investment is future-proof and can handle evolving government needs and planned enhancements.

step3_refined_points.title: Ensuring Security, Compliance, and Data Sovereignty
step3_refined_points.description: Adhering to strict ICT security and privacy policies is non-negotiable. The government is concerned about potential non-compliance and safeguarding sensitive data, especially with third-party AI, as it poses significant legal, operational, and public trust risks.

step3_refined_points.title: Validating AI Value and Mitigating Adoption Risk
step3_refined_points.description: As a risk-averse entity, the Department is hesitant to commit to large-scale deployment without proven results. They require evidence from successful government use cases and pilot initiatives to validate real-world effectiveness, justify investment, and build confidence.

step3_refined_points.title: Technical Integration and Future-Proofing
step3_refined_points.description: New AI must integrate with existing legacy systems without incurring excessive costs or technical challenges. The solution must also be scalable and mature enough to handle evolving government needs, ensuring any investment is future-proof and adaptable for planned enhancements.

step3_refined_points.title: Overcoming Internal Skills Gap and Training Burden
step3_refined_points.description: The Department is concerned that current staff lack the necessary skills to implement and manage new AI tools. This potential training burden could negatively impact project timelines, budget, and the overall success of adoption, creating a significant operational hurdle.
